awd_titl_txt: Collaborative: A mobile smart glucose monitoring system
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research proposal is to develop a class of novel mobile smart glucose monitoring system (mSGMS) that is able to detect glucose levels from interstitial fluid without the use of an external power source or a battery. In a clinical context, the work will provide a new technique for continuous glucose measurement that is far more effective at detecting transient changes in glucose levels. The mSGMS will provide faster analysis and better diagnostic information, with the added benefit of responding rapidly to abnormalities in glucose levels. The ability to continuously monitor glucose means it will no longer be necessary to frequently sample blood with some associated degree of inconvenience and pain.  The smart glucose monitoring system integrated with data transmission-communication modules could potentially replace continuous glucose monitors (CGMs) used in monitoring blood glucose in healthcare applications. Educational outreach activities and research experiences will be developed to engage Baltimore area high school students, undergraduates, and graduate students in the proposed research. This work will be of significant use in improving glycemic control and improving the quality of life with fewer complications and lower healthcare costs. 


A class of novel stretchable and flexible mobile smart glucose monitoring system (mSGMS) capable of continuous glucose measurement that is far more effective at detecting transient changes in glucose levels from interstitial fluid is proposed. The development of the mSGMS will be achieved through the following specific aims: (Aim 1) Design, fabricate and test the smart glucose monitoring system capable of detecting glucose levels. (Aim 2) Develop a mobile smart glucose monitoring system (mSGMS) that integrates wireless telemetry and performs data collection, signal processing, data analysis, and information transmission to patient and caregivers, and (Aim 3) encapsulate the smart glucose monitoring system. The proposed research is innovative because the mSGMS generates and accumulates electrical power in a capacitor via a charge pump integrated circuit (IC) as a result of the oxidation of interstitial glucose for sensing glucose without the use of a potentiostat circuit or an external power source, while simultaneously via a DC-DC converter powering the data acquisition, processing, and data transmission-communication modules. This research offers tremendous opportunities to overcome the limitations of commercially available glucose monitoring technologies by providing a device that allows sensitive and rapid detection of transient changes in interstitial glucose concentration. The proposed studies will generate continuous glucose recording in interstitial fluid samples from patients with type 1 diabetes for long duration.

por.por_cntn:
This proposed research aims to develop a mobile smart glucose monitoring system (mSGMS) that can detect glucose levels without using an external power source or a battery. Therefore, we explored using bacterial nanocellulose as substrate material for fabricating the 'skin-like' glucose monitor. Our proof-of-concept device, comprising an enzymatic glucose fuel cell, glucose sensor, and an LED indicator, does not require additional electronic equipment for detection or verification, and the entire structure collapses into a microns-thin, self-adhering, single-centimeter-square decal, weighing less than 40mg. The flexible glucose indicator system continuously operates an LED through a capacitive charge/discharge cycle, directly correlated to the glucose concentration (1 mM – 45 mM), and achieves a 1.8 VDC output from the flexible indicator system that delivers sufficient power to drive an LED circuit.

We integrated remote data access with the cost-effective portable glucose monitoring system based on a novel e-oscilloscope using the glucose indicator system interfaced to a microcontroller programmed to convert the charge/discharge rates of the capacitor functioning as a transducer. The capacitor charge/discharge rates were converted into glucose concentration readings that were monitored remotely. The anode was fabricated by modifying a gold microwire with nanoporous colloidal platinum (Au-co-Pt), and the cathode was constructed using a mesh dense network of multiwalled carbon nanotubes modified with bilirubin oxidase, respectively. The glucose monitoring system showed excellent sensitivity, increasing glucose concentration from 1 mM to 25 mM. In addition, the glucose monitoring system exhibited optimal operation at a pH of 7.4 and 37 °C, which is ideal for physiological glucose monitoring.

We demonstrated an ultra-thin, flexible glucose abiotic biofuel cell system capable of generating adequate bioelectricity using a facile three-step fabrication process. The abiotic glucose biofuel cell was constructed by first printing gold nanoparticle (AuNP) electrodes on 20 µm thin sheet bacterial nanocellulose (BNC) to serve as the anodic and cathodic base material, upon which we electrodeposited colloidal-Pt at the anode and drop cast a mixture of multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) and silver oxide nanoparticles (Ag2ONPs) at the cathode. The power output correlated to good glucose sensing performance. The facile method presented for the fabrication of the electrodes has the potential to enable the realization of various small form factor devices that provide a path to the mass production of cost-effective biofuel cells.

Additionally, we investigated the development of a printed flexible battery-less wireless glucose monitoring system comprising a glucose/O2 abiotic hybrid fuel cell and battery-less wireless module using NFC technology. The developed anodic and cathodic electrodes are decorated with co-Pt and Ag2O-MWCNT composite, respectively. The voltage generated from the developed abiotic hybrid fuel cell is correlated with glucose. The data transfer module used a low-power microcontroller that is enabled using a smartphone with an NFC antenna receiving the respective instantaneous voltage data from the abiotic hybrid fuel cell. Upon device integration of the abiotic glucose hybrid fuel cell with the NFC module, the data from the glucose monitoring system is successfully transmitted to an Android application for visualization at the user interface. The cell voltage correlated (r2 = 0.989) with glucose concentration (up to 19 mM) with a sensitivity of 13.9 mV/mM•cm2.

We have demonstrated a flexible battery-less wireless glucose monitoring system comprising a glucose abiotic hybrid fuel cell and battery-less wireless module using NFC technology. To enhance the power output of our flexible battery-less wireless glucose monitoring system, we explored incorporating a photo-driven (thylakoid membrane) component at the bioanode using laser-induced graphene (LIG). The electrochemical activities and stability of as-fabricated thylakoid-based bioanode were investigated. We optimize the thylakoid concentration to produce the highest current density for the bioanode. When combined with the co-Pt bioanode, the unique features of thylakoids are expected to play a critical role in producing a high-performance hybrid self-powered glucose monitoring system.

The research project developed a 'skin-like' mobile sensing system that continuously monitoring glucose levels. This is important for measuring transient changes in glucose levels and will increase knowledge and ability for the clinical management of diabetes and improve the self-care of diabetic patients. This will also minimize hospital visits and ultimately lead to the improvement in lifestyles for diabetic patients. This research has resulted in over 15 peer-reviewed journal articles and conference proceedings. 22 undergraduates, 3 M.S. students, and 4 Ph.D. students have been mentored on this project. The educational outreach through the Bioelectronics Summer Institute Program, a one-week residential academic program for rising 6th - 12th graders from underrepresented groups in STEM who express a desire to pursue a career in STEM, was a success. We hosted over 170 underrepresented middle and high school students in Hampton Roads to engage in STEM-related activities, specifically biosensors and bioelectronics, to build a pipeline into undergraduate and graduate studies. In summary, the proposed research created a mobile sensing system that continuously monitors glucose levels with a potential for broad societal impact in healthcare.
